question.text: Which of the following is not true regarding artificial insemination?

options.text: Ideal parents are carefully chosen before the female is impregnated.
The semen may be used immediately or can be frozen and used at a later date
The fertilised eggs at 8–32 cells stages, are recovered from the original parent non-surgically and transferred to surrogate mothers.
It helps in overcoming several problems of normal matings.

solution.text:
Controlled breeding experiments are carried out using artificial insemination. The semen is collected from the male that is chosen as a parent and injected into the reproductive tract of the selected female by the breeder. The semen may be used immediately or can be frozen and used at a later date. It can also be transported in a frozen form to where the female is housed. In this way desirable matings are carried. Artificial insemination helps us overcome several problems of normal matings. 
In MOET, a cow is administered hormones, with FSH-like activity, to induce follicular maturation and super ovulation – instead of one egg, which they normally yield per cycle, they produce 6-8 eggs. The animal is either mated with an elite bull or artificially inseminated. The fertilised eggs at 8–32 cells stages, are recovered non-surgically and transferred to surrogate mothers. The genetic mother is available for another round of super ovulation.
